channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Exclusive: Inside US-UN plan to remake funding for humanitarian crises
item.description: A confidential memorandum of understanding signals a shift in balance of power among U.N. relief agencies.

item.title: From crisis grants to open calls: Novo Nordisk Foundation’s aid work
item.description: As aid budgets shrink, the Novo Nordisk Foundation is rethinking global development by combining systems-level research, flexible funding, and rapid humanitarian response — focused on NCDs, food systems, and climate resilience in LMICs.

item.title: Devex Invested: Sizing up AIIB’s new grievance rules
item.description: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank updates grievance rules, winning cautious civil society optimism; what’s inside the latest U.S. foreign aid numbers; and where to find $1.3 trillion in climate finance.

item.title: Many European Governments Are Retreating on a Human Rights Treaty, Experts Say
item.description: A bloc of European governments is pushing judges to read Europe’s main human rights treaty more narrowly, arguing that courts are letting “irregular” migrants and even foreign nationals convicted of serious crimes stay in a country when they should be removed. Rights groups and legal scholars say the move is less about fixing legal gaps ... Read more

item.title: Books: A Peep Into Claude McKay’s “Letters in Exile”
item.description: Nomadic Jamaican-American writer Claude McKay probably never dreamed that 21st-century readers would be delving into his private correspondence some 77 years after his death. But that’s probably part of the professional hazard (luck?) of being a literary luminary, or, as Yale University Press describes him, “one of the Harlem Renaissance’s brightest and most radical voices”. […]

item.title: Development needs new narratives of hope. Are we ready to invest in them?
item.description: Opinion: Global development's crisis of hope won't be solved by celebrating massive institutional wins. It requires painstaking investment in documenting the successes, and glimmers of hope that keep communities going.

item.title: Devex Newswire: US Congress gives aid supporters $50B boost
item.description: The funding bill would provide some $50 billion for U.S. foreign assistance programs in fiscal year 2026. Plus, U.S.-Africa trade act gets new life from legislators.

item.title: Ukraine war: UN appeals for $2.3 billion to support aid teams’ ‘heroic work’
item.description: Amid ongoing and intensifying Russian attacks across Ukraine, the UN on Tuesday launched a $2.3 billion humanitarian appeal for 2026 to support 4.1 million of the country’s most vulnerable people.

item.title: Gaza: A ceasefire that still kills children is not enough, says UNICEF
item.description: Airstrikes, drone attacks and hypothermia continue in Gaza despite the ceasefire, with more than 100 youngsters killed since early October, the UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) said on Tuesday.

item.title: Iran: ‘The killing of peaceful demonstrators must stop,’ UN rights chief says
item.description: As anti-government demonstrations continue across Iran, the UN human rights chief said on Tuesday that he was horrified at the mounting violence directed by security forces against protestors, with reports of hundreds killed and thousands arrested.

item.title: Increase taxes on sugary drinks and alcohol to save lives, urges WHO
item.description: Beverages like sugary drinks and alcohol are too accessible and cost too little in most of the world – helping fuel obesity, diabetes, cancer and injury, the World Health Organization (WHO) warned on Tuesday.

item.title: Development leaders must win the narrative battle or disappear
item.description: Opinion: Most people can name the leaders of Tesla and Meta, but not the heads of organizations protecting climate, democracy, and nature. In today’s media landscape, that invisibility is a death sentence.

item.title: US House passes extension of African Growth and Opportunity Act
item.description: A strong bipartisan majority approved the three-year extension of the U.S.-Africa trade program, providing a bridge for negotiations on a permanent update.

item.title: US Congress backs Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, despite Trump admin cuts
item.description: Six months ago the Trump administration said it would cut funding for Gavi but the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives included funding for it in its foreign assistance appropriations bill.

item.title: Roots of Evil: Ethnic cleansing in Europe and the U.S.
item.description: At the moment, ICE’s advancement in the U.S. is apparently dividing the nation’s population into desired and undesirable elements. The Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) was born after the September 11, 2001 attacks on the Twin Towers and intended to be a response to terrorism. However, with Donald Trump’s return to the White House, federal […]

item.title: Richest 1% have Blown Through their Fair Share of Carbon Emissions for 2026 –in just 10 Days
item.description: The richest 1% have exhausted their annual carbon budget – the amount of CO2 that can be emitted while staying within 1.5 degrees of warming – only ten days into the year, according to new analysis from Oxfam. The richest 0.1% already used up their carbon limit on the 3rd January. This day – named […]

item.title: Is the US Moving Towards the UN’s Exit Door?
item.description: Judging by the mass US withdrawal from 66 UN entities, including UN conventions and international treaties*, is it remotely possible that the unpredictable Trump administration may one day decide to pull out of the UN, and force the Secretariat out of New York– despite the 1947 UN-US headquarters agreement? Besides the 66, the withdrawals also […]
